Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Gastric Partitioning versus Gastrojejunostomy for Malignant Gastric Outlet Obstruction

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was performed using computer-generated software

Participants.evidence: patients aged 18-85 with obstructive, unresectable distal gastric adenocarcinoma

Intervention.evidence: compare the efficacy of gastric partitioning versus gastrojejunostomy

Objective.evidence: aimed to compare the efficacy of gastric partitioning versus gastrojejunostomy

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the acceptance of a full diet (GOOS 3) at discharge

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using computer-generated software, with allocation concealed until after consent

Blinding.evidence: The trial was open-label, with no blinding of participants or clinicians

Number_Randomised.evidence: Between August 2013 and April 2020, 90 patients were randomised

Number_Analysed.evidence: 25 in the gastrojejunostomy group and 27 in the partitioning group were analysed per-protocol

Result_Outcome.evidence: Acceptance of a normal diet was significantly higher in the partitioning group (96% vs. 72%; p = 0.022)

Harms.evidence: The partitioning group had more frequent red blood cell transfusions (81% vs. 52%; p = 0.024)
